question: Coverage for lawfully present immigrants
text:
Coverage for lawfully present immigrants
          
        
Lawfully present immigrants are eligible for coverage through Virginia's Insurance Marketplace.
The term lawfully present includes immigrants who have:


Qualified non-citizen immigration status without a waiting period (see details below).




Humanitarian statuses or circumstances (including Temporary Protected Status, Special Juvenile Status, asylum applicants, Convention Against Torture, victims of trafficking).



Valid non-immigrant visas.



Legal status conferred by other laws (temporary resident status, LIFE Act, Family Unity individuals).
See a full list of immigration statuses eligible for Coverage through Virginia's Insurance Marketplace.


Lawfully present immigrants and premium savings

If youre a lawfully present immigrant, Virginia's Insurance Marketplace can get you covered. You may be eligible for lower costs on monthly premiums and lower out-of-pocket costs based on your household income.

You may still qualify for premium tax credits that reduce the cost of your health coverage in 2022.

Immigrants and Medicaid & Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS)
Immigrants who are qualified non-citizens are generally eligible for coverage through Medicaid and the Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS), if you meet Virginia Medicaid requirements.
In order to qualify for Medicaid and FAMIS coverage, many qualified non-citizens (such as many Lawfully Permanent Residents or green card holders) have a 5-year waiting period, also known as the 5-year bar. This means they must wait 5 years after receiving "qualified" immigration status before they are eligible for Medicaid and FAMIS coverage. However, there are exceptions. In Virginia, children aged 18 or younger, pregnant women, refugees, asylees, or lawful permanent residents who used to be refugees or asylees dont have to wait 5 years to qualify for Medicaid or FAMIS
The term qualified non-citizen includes:

Lawful Permanent Residents (LPR/Green Card Holder)


Asylees



Refugees



Cuban/Haitian entrants



Paroled into the U.S. for at least one year



Conditional entrant granted before 1980



Battered non-citizens, spouses, children, or parents



Victims of trafficking and his or her spouse, child, sibling, or parent or individuals with a pending application for a victim of trafficking visa



Granted withholding of deportation



Member of a federally recognized Indian tribe or American Indian born in Canada



Citizens of the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau who are living in one of the U.S. states or territories (referred to as Compact of Free Association or COFA migrants)


Medicaid & the Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS) coverage for lawfully residing children and pregnant women

In Virginia lawfully residing children and pregnant women can enroll in Medicaid and the Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS) without a five-year waiting period. A child or pregnant woman is "lawfully residing" if theyre "lawfully present" and otherwise eligible for Medicaid or the Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS) in the State of Virginia.

Medicaid, the Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS), Virginia's Insurance Marketplace and Public Charge:

On March 11, 2021, President Biden formally rescinded the public charge rule, so it is not in effect. Applying for, and/or enrolling, in health coverage through Medicaid, the Family Access to Medical Insurance Security Plan (FAMIS), or Virginia's Insurance Marketplace will not make someone a public charge or affect their ability to become a Lawful Permanent Resident (LPR) or U.S. citizen in the future.
